vectorData.altText: 1. Put the layers in the scalp in order from superficial to deep.
That's right! From superficial to deep, the scalp consists of 5 layers: Skin, Connective tissue (dense), Aponeurosis, Loose connective tissue, Periosteum.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

The scalp is a complex, multilayered structure covering the neurocranium. It extends from the superior border of the orbit, anteriorly, to the external occipital protuberance and adjacent part of the occipital bone, posteriorly. Laterally it extends down to the level of the zygomatic arch. 
It consists of 5 layers. The outermost 3 layers adhere tightly to each other, and, from superficial to deep, consist of the skin, a layer of dense connective tissue (CT) and an aponeurotic layer. The layer of dense CT is well vascularized and it adheres to the vessels. This prevents the vessels from constricting when cut, which is why scalp lacerations typically bleed profusely
Deep to the aponeurosis is a layer of very loose CT. This is why it is so easy to slide the scalp back and forth on the skull. Unfortunately, this layer offers little resistance, and acts as a cleavage plane that makes it relatively easy to separate from the skull. It also offers little resistance to the spread of infections which gain entry to this layer. 
The deepest layer of the 5 layers in the scalp is the periosteum of the skull. You will recall from the histology eModule on bone, that periosteum is the dense irregular CT layer that surrounds bone.
